conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on each block and understand the system behavior when force is applied to block B.
Assume no friction between the blocks and the surface since they are identical and placed on a smooth horizontal surface.
Spring connecting blocks B and C is within its elastic limit, obeying Hooke's Law.
Objective is to determine the magnitude of the static friction force acting on block D.
Blocks B and C are connected by a spring, which exerts a force on block C when block B is pulled.
Force F applied to block B is transmitted through the spring to block C, and then to blocks D and A.
Force F causes block B to accelerate, and the spring transmits this force to block C.
Block C pushes block D forward due to the spring force.
Block A is pushed forward by block B directly.
Spring force Fs acts between blocks B and C, responsible for accelerating block C and subsequently block D.
Spring is light and within its elastic limit, not adding significant mass to the system.
Block D is pushed forward by block C and not directly connected to block B or the spring.
Surface is smooth, so there is no friction between the blocks and the surface.
Static friction force on block D is the force required to keep block D moving with the same acceleration as the other blocks.
Total mass of the system is 4m, where m is the mass of each block.
Acceleration a of the system is given by a = F / 4m.
Block D is accelerated by the force transmitted through block C.
Force required to accelerate block D is m * a.
On a smooth surface, the static friction force is zero because there is no resistance to motion.
Static friction force acting on block D during the acceleration process is zero.
